Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Characterizing Regenerative Cells during Central Nervous System Regeneration in Marine Acorn Worms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Central nervous system (CNS) regeneration remains on the forefront of scientific research after decades of study. Progress and advances have been made, however, many of the cellular mechanisms controlling CNS regeneration continue to be elusive. Millions of people suffer from debilitating neurological defects, like Alzheimer?s and Parkinson?s disease, spina bifida, epilepsy, and spinal cord injuries, to name a few. Furthermore, aging and age related diseases eventually affect everyone. Regeneration may slow the aging process and stem cells, which have the potential to become any type of cell in the body, including nerve cells, present one feasible way to combat neural diseases and injuries. The goal of this project is to determine whether bona fide stem cells are elaborating missing tissue during regeneration in marine acorn worms. Some species of acorn worms, like Ptychodera flava, completely regenerate their entire CNS after amputation. Understanding the mechanisms for regeneration in acorn worms may yield clues to unlocking regeneration in other animals with limited CNS regeneration, including humans. I will be working with Dr. Yi-Hsien Su at the Institute of Cellular and Organismic Biology at Academia Sinica in Taiwan on this project. She routinely collects and uses this animal for biological studies. Her lab specializes in gene networks regulating animal body plan evolution, development, and patterning using molecular techniques that target specific genes and cell types. This project may be a springboard that could give insights for new stem cell therapies and nerve regeneration in humans.

Acorn worms, also known as hemichordates, are marine, invertebrate deuterostomes and sister group to the echinoderms. Acorn worms have a tripartite body plan with an anterior proboscis, a middle collar region, and a long posterior trunk. As deuterostomes, hemichordates share several morphological and developmental features with the chordates. The solitary hemichordate, Ptychodera flava, has a hollow, dorsal neural tube that develops in a very similar fashion to the chordate neural tube. Upon amputation, P. flava reliably regrows their entire neural tube and anterior head-like structure in about two weeks. No chordate has been shown to have this ability. Our lab has shown that extensive cell death and cell proliferation are activated during anterior regeneration in P. flava. It is not known whether bona fide stem cells are proliferating in this animal or whether somatic cells are de-differentiating and then becoming multi-potent to generate new structures. To help confirm the origin and identity of proliferating cells in P. flava, I will stain non-regenerating animals with antibodies raised against a hemichordate vasa protein. Vasa is a marker for germline stem cells across numerous animal phyla. Vasa is also expressed in some non-germline, multi-potent stem cells. I will also use in situ hybridization with the stem cell markers, c-Myc, pax6, and alkaline phosphatase. If expression of these markers co-localize with staining of vasa protein in non-germ cells, this will support a hypothesis of bona fide stem cells in P. flava. If this is confirmed, P. flava presents an exciting model to study the molecular mechanisms of stem cell recruitment and specification during central nervous system regeneration in the deuterostomes. Further experiments will be required to prove that the stem cells can self renew and also differentiate into other cell types during regeneration.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAPSI 2016 Project Outcome Report

            Ptychodera flava is a marine acorn worm that, surprisingly, shares many common features with humans. This humble little hemichordate worm found throughout the Indo-Pacific Ocean has developmental similarities, as well as thousands of genes and gene networks matching the human genome. Even more remarkable, P. flava can regenerate all of their organs and tissues, including a central nervous system (CNS), when bisected into two pieces in the trunk. Humans have lost the ability to regenerate most tissues, especially in the CNS, but we may be able to achieve more robust regeneration using models made from animals like P. flava. We published an article in Developmental Dynamics last year describing P. flava regeneration in detail (DOI: 10.1002/dvdy.24457). We showed the internal and external morphology and identified nearly a thousand genes that are regulated during CNS regeneration. Our publication even made national and international headlines after it was featured in UW Today, the University of Washington’s news bulletin (http://www.washington.edu/news/2016/11/28/our-closest-worm-kin-regrow-body-parts-raising-hopes-of-regeneration-in-humans/). My EAPSI project aimed to build on this research and answer a key question regarding the type of cells P. flava uses to elaborate missing tissue.

            Our lab has shown that P. flava hemichordates regenerate missing tissue by adding new cells through cell division. The question that remains is where do these dividing cells come from? There are only two options. It may be possible that existing cells in the animal, like heart cells or nerve cells or some other type of cell loses its cell fate, or dedifferentiates, and then becomes a stem cell that is able to divide and become another type of cell in the new tissue. The other possibility is that stem cells are always in the tissue whether the animal is regenerating or not, and these stem cells become active after injury or amputation and begin to divide. This is critical to know because if the first option is true, it will give us a model to study mechanisms necessary for the gain and loss of cell fates. In humans, when a cell differentiates, its fate usually cannot be altered. For example, a heart cell will never become a nerve cell. If the latter option is true, however, it will give us a model to study stem cell maintenance, recruitment, and specification during regeneration of tissue.   

            Stem cells (SC) in humans express certain genes in the genome and can be identified using specific antibodies and RNA probes. Confirming the presence of one protein or expression of one gene is not sufficient evidence to support a claim of one particular cell type, since many cell types overlap in parts of their genetic profile. In light of this, I used several SC markers in my EAPSI project in both adult animals and larvae to determine whether known stem cell markers co-localize in the same cells in both regenerating and uninjured, non-regenerating animals.

            For this project, I travelled to Taiwan, to a lab that has been making antibodies to stem cell markers in P. flava. I used markers for the piwi, vasa, c-myc and pax6 genes. In addition to using these stem cell markers, I also stained tissue with EdU to target cells that are undergoing cell division. EdU is a molecule that gets incorporated into DNA during cell division. The goal was to see if cells expressing stem cell markers were also actively dividing. One of the hallmarks of stem cells is their ability to proliferate or divide. If P. flava does have genuine stem cells, I expect to see some of these cells stain positive with EdU combined with the other SC markers.

            This was my first time to Taiwan and it was fascinating to learn about the culture of the people and work in the labs. The adult P. flava worms there all had parasites that I’d never seen before from other populations in Hawaii, Tahiti, and Japan. These parasites seem to hinder adult regeneration, but future studies will be needed to examine this more closely to determine the effect parasites are having on tissue regeneration. While in Taiwan I also learned how to culture P. flava larvae and I am continuing that project now in our lab at the University of Washington. I made many new friends and potential future collaborators during my EAPSI experience. I worked hard and I uncovered exciting new data that we are currently building on and combining with ongoing research. We plan to publish this data by the end of summer. I have given three talks to scientists and the general public about my research experience through the EAPSI program and data from this project will also contribute to the final chapter of my Ph.D. dissertation. I am very grateful for this unique opportunity.
